text.p: Heating and building materials group Hepworth Plc on Friday predicted "steady progress" on the back of improved growth prospects across Europe, which it said should stimulate new construction and home improvement spending.
The company reported a slight fall in first-half pre-tax profit to 35.5 million stg from 37.5 million a year earlier in what it described as "challenging conditions".

Chief executive John Carter said in a statement that the group was continuing to develop its internationals potential, with good progress being made on the two Chinese and one Spanish manufaturing operations commissioned over the past year.

"Hepworth's strong financial position will be applied to the development of key product growth and appropriate acquisitions," Carter said, adding that "vigorous action will be taken to ensure competitiveness."

The group said its pretax profits were affected by redundancy charges of 2.4 million stg, compared with 1.1 million a year before, and higher pension charges, partly offset by property disposals. The group's gearing declined to 15.6 percent at the end of the first half from 22.3 percent a year before.
The group said Pierre Franken is to replace Jean-Francois Chene as head of Hepworth Saunier Duval on December 1.
Exports from all UK divisions continued to rise, gaining 24 percent in the first six months of 1996.
Operating profits and sales fell at Hepworth building products, affected by weak UK housing starts, a "marked fall" in new road building and cold weather in continental Europe.
Sales and operating profits rose at Hepworth Home Products.
Sales at the French heating unit Saunier Duval were helped by exchange rate benefits and new products,although operating profits fell slightly due to higher redundancy costs.
"This was a good performance when considered against the generally subdued market for gas boilers," Hepworth said.
